conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the motion of the bullets and the carts in the frame of reference of the ground using principles of relative velocity and the relationship between distances traveled by the bullets and the carts.
The speed of the bullet relative to the ground is the vector sum of its speed relative to the cart and the speed of the cart itself.

Since the bullet is fired horizontally and the carts are moving in opposite directions, the speed of the bullet relative to the ground is either \(v_0 - v_1\) (if Cart A is moving to the left) or \(v_0 + v_2\) (if Cart B is moving to the right).
The problem states that the speed of each bullet relative to the ground remains constant at \(v_0\), so the relative motion of the bullet and the cart must adjust to maintain this constant speed.
The speed of the bullet relative to the cart must adjust to ensure the speed of the bullet relative to the ground is always \(v_0\).
The distance between two adjacent bullets in the air is \(s\), and the time interval between the firing of the bullets is \(\Delta t_0\).
The distance traveled by the bullet in the time interval \(\Delta t_0\) is \(s = v_0 \Delta t_0\).
Solving for \(\Delta t_0\), we get \(\Delta t_0 = \frac{s}{v_0}\).
In the time interval \(\Delta t_0\), the distance traveled by the bullet is \(s\).
The distance traveled by Cart A in the time interval \(\Delta t_0\) is \(v_1 \Delta t_0\).
The distance traveled by Cart B in the time interval \(\Delta t_0\) is \(v_2 \Delta t_0\).
Since the bullet hits the target on Cart B, the distance traveled by the bullet must equal the distance traveled by Cart B plus the initial distance between the carts.
The problem does not provide the initial distance between the carts, so we need a relationship that does not depend on the initial distance.
The key is to use the fact that the speed of the bullet relative to the ground is constant and the time interval between the firing of the bullets is \(\Delta t_0\).
